item.description:
The players lead a horde of monsters attempting to pillage various civilizations in EVENIA. To win, be the player with the most “Pillage Points” by the end of the game.
 Pillage! is a card game where each player controls a race of monsters attacking villages in Evenia. Each pillage deck acts as the location the monsters are pillaging; both its rich bountiful booty ripe for the taking and the powerful defenses set to stop the vile creatures.

Inside the decks are loot, goods, weapons, and other ransacking potential, but also knights, militia, mercenaries, walls, and other various things to stop the monsters’ onslaught. Many of these monsters do not play well together and will attempt to steal and harm one another just to be the winner.

The game ends when the final card is drawn from the Pillage Deck. At that time the area is considered fully pillaged and the monsters leave to search for another place to ransack.

Get ready for big-time NFL action in a game for the whole family!
Players split into teams and a coin flip starts the game. The offense rolls the dice to keep the drive alive, while the defense tries to force a turnover.
Suit up as your favorite team and pass, kick, and score just like the pros. Call the right play to score the winning touchdown and keep track on the scorecard for bragging rights later!

item.description:
Who's most likely to report a UFO sighting? Albert Einstein, Marilyn Monroe, Superman, Abraham Lincoln or Mrs. Kenmore - your third grade teacher? Who would dress up to visit a nudist camp? Cheat on an exam? Be recruited by the CIA? From celebrities and politicians to fictional characters and even your now famous ex… no one is spared in the game where the majority always rules!

After nominating five "candidates" players draw question cards that place the characters in awkward, ludicrous or extreme situations, then vote for the one they believe the situation applies to most. The majority wins, but you'll enjoy watching your friends defend their selected candidates, no matter how absurd their claims might be.

item.description:
This is mildly educational roll and move board game. Game's name comes from Finnish Science Center Heureka.

In the game you will travel through Europe by throwing dice. In certain places in your way, there are cities where you have to solve some rudimentary mathematical problems. When you solve the problem you can go on. Most of the problems have something to do with probability and to "solve" the problem you will throw some dice, draw some cards or arrange fibonacci numbers in right order. Game includes traditional card deck and 3*6D, 8D, 12D and the two non-normal 20-sided dice. First player who gets back to Heureka Science Center is the winner.

That dad-blam Sheriff has gone too far this time! He's ridin' the rails with his corrupt and wealthy friends, while the good folks of this territory are stuck in poverty. No sir, that just ain't right! We aim to bring justice to the West, and the only way to do that is to rob that there train and see that the good folks of this county get the spoils!

In Train Heist, up to four players work together to board the train, loot the passengers and cargo, and vamoose with the goods before the Sheriff catches you! Bring enough finery back to each town before the train arrives to keep the Sheriff at bay. If you can pull this off, everybody wins, but be careful because if enough perilous events occur or a hangman noose is tied up, it's game over for all!

name.value: Sailor Moon: Quest of the Guardian Card Game

item.description:
"The Sailor Scouts, along with the Guardians, have banded together to battle the forces of the Negaverse! Be the first Sailor Scout to send the most "Enemies" back to the Negaverse and win the game."

A children's card game where the objective is to collect "Negaverse" cards by players turning the top card of their deck over and saying the name of the character on the card out loud if there are any matching cards revealed.

There are two types of cards: Negaverse and Sailor Scout Cards. The cards are separated into decks of their type; the Sailor Scout cards which include the Sailor Scout character cards, Luna cards and Artemis cards are shuffled and distributed to every player evenly. The Negaverse Cards (back of cards are labeled "Negaverse") are kept face down in a separate pile.

Players would then countdown to reveal the top card of their deck. When a player correctly names the matching cards that are revealed, the player obtains a Negaverse card from the pile. If special "Luna" or "Artemis" cards are revealed it enables the player to make card trades with another player. Play continues until all Negaverse cards are claimed and the player with the greatest number of Negaverse cards is the winner.

In La Granja, players control small farms by the Alpich pond near the village of Esporles on the island of Mallorca. Over time, the players develop their farms and deliver goods to the village. Players are vying to earn the title of "La Granja" for their country estate!

Over the course of 6 game rounds, players will expand their farm by adding fields, farm extensions, market barrows, and helpers. They will earn VPs by delivering goods to the village of Esporles. It is important to observe the actions of other players, manipulate turn order, and adjust your strategy based on the dice and cards.

La Granja is a fascinating game that requires careful planning. Timing and speed is crucial. However, successful players must cope with the uncertainty of events during the game. The player who has earned the most victory points at the end of the game is the winner and new owner of the La Granja estate!

item.description:
Wildcatters is a tactical and strategic board game set during the booming business of the 19th century oil industry!

The players are oil barons who develop oil fields; bid for oil rights; and build rigs, oil tankers, trains, and refineries. Your goal is to deliver more oil barrels to the continents than the other players while also collecting more shares and money than them.

The game lasts seven rounds with four players, and the game set-up is the same for each player, with three rigs, two trains, one tanker and one refinery being placed on the board. The game board features a world map divided into eight areas where you can find oil. Players choose an open area card and get money to build rigs, tankers, trains and refineries, after which they can buy oil actions. The players work together in an oilfield to find oil at a lower cost. The players transport oil together to the refineries, using trains and tankers from other players to deliver oil to the refineries – and all with one purpose: deliver more oil than the other players by the end of the game.

item.description:
The turkeys on the farm are feasting away, but they must be careful! When Thanksgiving comes around, those turkeys that have made the deepest impression on the farm owner make perfect candidates to appear on the Thanksgiving dinner table. Would you, as a turkey in this game, be able to pig out with all that yummy food, but without becoming a dish yourself?

Happy Turkey Day! is a simultaneous-move game with each player taking the role of a voracious turkey. In the beginning of each round, each player takes one of the Action tokens in his/her hands, and places it, face down, on the playing surface in front of him/her. Then, all players turn over their tokens simultaneously and take an action: either grabbing some Food from a Hen House (i.e. Eat), or exercising to trim down a bit
(i.e. Lose Weight).

Each player has two goals in this game: first, getting a balanced diet by obtaining a variety of different Food cards – the wider the variety and the more the Food cards a player gets, the better the score; at the same time, each player should try to avoid getting marked Chubby whenever the Farm Owner makes an inspection to identify candidates for his Thanksgiving turkey dinner. At each inspection, the chubbiest turkey (as indicated by the highest number of Food cards held) will be given Chubby Markers. When Thanksgiving comes around, the turkey with the most Chubby Markers will be sent to the dinner table!

At the end of Thanksgiving, the survival turkey with the highest score wins! How to collect as many Food cards as possible, while avoiding getting Chubby Markers, is the key to winning this game.

item.description:
Tatu ja Patu – Virheistä viis has cards with two pictures. Players must find 5, 10 or 15 differences in the pictures and mark them on the cards with whiteboard pens. Players score 0-5 points depending on how many differences they find. There are several rounds played until someone gets 25 points.

The game art is based on popular Tatu and Patu children's books by Sami Toivonen and Aino Havukainen. The game play is based on Spot the Difference from University Games.

MLB Chipz is a basic dexterity game from Topps using themed, collectible poker chips. The components are themed poker chips with a baseball-inspired design and featuring MLB players. The chips come in several variants such as magnetic, glow-in-the-dark, and metallic but the variants do not affect game play. The game board is reminiscent of a baseball diamond, with scoring zones marked for value. The themed components do not impact game play. Each package contains four random chips, a sticker, and a game board.

Rules are included on the back of the game board for three dexterity games: Shuffle Chipz, Flip Chipz, and Spin Chipz. In all three games, the board is laid flat with the final resting position of the chip determining the score. In Shuffle Chipz, chips are slid onto the board and players have the opportunity to knock away opposing chips. In Flip Chipz, chips are flipped onto the board, and chips landing face up score double. In Spin Chipz, the chip is placed in the middle of the board and spun. The goal of the game is to accumulate the highest score within a set number of rounds.

Chain of Command are the revolutionary new wargames rules designed for platoon sized actions with some additional support. The rules are fast paced, exciting and fun, using the unique command and control system which presents the player with the battlefield decisions made by his historical counterpart. These are the rules Neil Shuck of Miniature Wargames described as "probably the best set of Skirmish rules I've ever played".

At 104 pages, the book includes the rules, a scenario generation system and Army Lists for Britain, Germans, the United States and Soviet Union, a system allowing the gamer to select support depending on the scenario being played, so you can pit two well matched forces against each other for a fun and challenging gaming experience.

item.description:
Gunslingers'' is a card game set in the wild west, where each player must build up a posse of gunslingers to fight it out to the death. The player with the last gunslinger left alive wins the game.

During the game set up procedure location cards are randomly placed to create a western town for the players to move around. Each location the players visit opens up options that they can interact with to aid them in building up a strong group of gunslingers.

Starting the game with just one gunslinger card each, the players must move around the town and reach specific locations to play action cards, hire gunslingers or buy and sell items or weapons in an effort to build up their posse and eventually shoot it out to the death.

By buying Items or weapons the players can enhance their gunslingers abilities during specific actions, such as giving a gunslinger a holster during a shoot out action will make them faster on the draw.

The action cards get the players gambling at the saloon, mining at the mine, brawling outside the sheriffs office and capturing gunslingers from the rival posses, only then marching them off to the gallows and sending the prisoner to boot hill. Many more actions cards exist that can change the strategies of the game, like the explosion card, that could blow up the train station and thus prevent the only place the players can go to hire more gunslingers, their only choice would be to wait until it was rebuilt.

As soon as one player has hired a gunslinger from the train station, the fighting can begin so you had better earn some cash fast and be that first player or you may be sent to boot hill sooner than you think........

Publisher Blurb:

In Spy Alley Dice, each player becomes a spy for their given country. Players roll the dice for a chance to guess their opponents identities. If a player rolls 3 of a kind, they may take a guess of any player as the spy that is on the three dice. If a player rolls five of a kind, they may either guess a player as any spy, or they may take a big chance and try to accomplish their mission. To accomplish their mission, the player that rolled the 5 of a kind must ask each player in a clockwise manner if they want to guess him as the spy identity on the dice. If no player is willing to make a guess and the player is the spy on the dice, that player has accomplished his mission and wins the game. Otherwise, the last player remaining in the game is the winner.

name.value: Gen D'Armes: Rules for a Medieval Wargame

item.description:
Late Medieval/Early Renaissance wargame rules that use a map-based simultaneous movement system to indicate where units will move each turn. A unit's status is tracked on a simple roster that records losses to the unit. Troops also have an assigned relative points value that can be used for play-balance.

Shooting resolution uses a number of six-sided dice (D6), while melee resolution uses the cumulative melee values of the stands engaged multiplied by the result of a single average die (2-3-3-4-4-5) and the totals compared. There is also shock combat resolution to take account of the impetus of charging troops.

A stand of miniatures is removed after a specific number of roster hits are recorded. The amount required varies by the type of unit; for example, peasants remove a stand for every two hits, while knights remove stands after five hits.

Gen D'Armes is a playable set of rules that has stood the test of time and uses some well thought-out mechanics. There is also a section for siege battles.

name.value: A Brilliant Combat: The Battle of Manila Bay

item.description:
“Our fleet engaged the enemy in brilliant combat, protected by the Cavite and Manila forts. They obliged the enemy, with heavy loss, to maneuver repeatedly. At 9 o’clock the American Squadron took refuge behind the foreign shipping, on the east side of the bay. Our fleet, considering the enemy’s superiority, naturally suffered severe loss…. There was considerable loss of life.” –Spanish Admiral Montojo’s telegraph to Madrid during the battle.

A Brilliant Combat is the “sister” title of Death Before Dishonor: The Battle of Santiago that was the 2013 CSW Gold Level Donation reward. Like its counterpart the game uses a very simple and fun to play design that models the history well without a lot of record-keeping, and is also very solitaire play friendly. The game features the historical battle, several what-ifs, as well as scenarios that posit the Spanish Reserve Fleet sailing to take back the Philippines, or the German Asiatic Squadron challenging Admiral Dewey’s for control of the archipelago.

Each copy of A Brilliant Combat has one 11 by 17 inch map, one sheet of 77 single-sided, un-mounted counters, one players’ aide sheet and a 4 page rule book. Graphics are by Bruce Yearian. A Brilliant Combat sells for $11.95 plus shipping. Mounted counters can be had for an additional $5.00.

Translated from the back of the box:

Move It is an entertaining and social family game which makes your spare time efficient time.
Move It makes activity a game, and is the perfect solution to a more active way of life.
Move It is won by making a series of simple and funny physical exercises, which can be made by healthy kids and adults.
All exercises can be done indoors, and are developed in cooperation with leading experts in health and sports.

User description:
Players roll dice to move their pawn around on a field track. Passing the 100 meters, 200 meters, 300 meters or 400 meters line makes you draw a card describing a physical exercise you have to do. If you do the exercise correctly you will get a gold medal. First to 10 gold medals win the game. Medals can be lost by meeting other players pawns or the trainer.

The last remnants of Humanity fight a desperate resistance against an Alien invasion that has taken over Earth. A board game for 2-7 players pits a group of up to 6 marines against an enemy player who controls the Aliens. Featuring mission based play, a modular board, a campaign based skill and equipment system, and variable enemy selection that gives a new game experience every time you play.

Players alternate turns between the Marines and the Alien commander. During a Marines turn they choose between moving, firing weapons, using skills, activating Psionic or Tech powers, and destroying nearby enemy spawn locations. In between each marines players turn the Alien Commander activates a number of his Aliens based upon they type of Spawn Points he purchased at the start of the game.

Aliens vary from the melee centric but hard hitting powerhouses of the Pharid, to the robotic utilitarian legions, and finally Alien commandos sent in to personally deal with the Marine resistance.

Marine player pick from a variety of 10 total Marine Classifications ranging from the Short range centric Assault Marine and Long range specialist the Sniper to the Drone controlling Engineer and the offensive Assault Psion.

At the end of each mission the Marines pull from a requisition deck to outfit themselves with new equipment and draw from skill decks to increase the effectiveness of their Marines. These skills and new toys have a cost, they increase the Rank value of the overall Marine and contribute to the pool of Rank Points that the Alien Commander uses to purchase Alien Spawn Points to use against the Marine on their next mission.

A boxed set of six card games:

Bang! Zoom!

Players start with six cards each, which are used to spell words. The first person to spell BANG gets a 10 point bonus. Once this occurs, when someone spells ZOOM, they get a 10 point bonus and the game ends. Points are scored for each letter used in words. The winner is the player with the most points.

Hooey

You’ve got to be sharp. You’ve got to be shifty. Announce which cards you’re laying face down. Whether you tell the truth is up to you. Any player can then question your honesty. If they’re right - you get the pile, if they’re wrong - they do! First player to get rid of all their cards wins.

Rats!

Kid's game of pure luck. Cards are dealt face down to all players. Turn up cards in rotation and put them in the center; if you turn up a Big Fat Rat (rather than a Random Rat), you get all the cards in the center, unless the next player can also turn up a BFR. Object is to collect all the cards.

Royal Fluster

Players are dealt five cards from a modified standard deck and attempt to put together a Royal Flush by drawing and discarding cards. If you discard an Ace, you must draw a Fluster card and follow the instructions, hoping not to be harmed. The first player to make a royal flush wins the game.

Spit!

Each player deals 4 stacks with 7 down and the 8th card up. Play with only one hand (right, unless left-handed). At the same time, all players turn one card from the remaining deck face up in the center to start N piles. All may add to any pile. Ignore suits and colors. Build up or down, and change directions if you want: 5-6-7-6-7-6-7-8-9, etc. Numbers make a complete circle: 10-J-Q-K-A-2-3-4. Play only one card at a time from the top of of a stack onto a center pile; do not move cards sideways to create sequences on own stacks. Keep playing until ALL have used all their card piles.

Three Throws

This game has a theme of rock-scissors-paper. It is played in two different rounds. In the first round, players take turns turning up cards on a face-down tableau. If they turn up a set of winners, these cards are taken into hand. When all of the card possible are taken, the second round begins, which is essentially a game of war between players.

Players enlist a pirate crew trying to get the most valuable loot at the end of the game.
Pirate Rush is a role selection game for 2-4 players of about 45 minutes long.

34 treasure tiles are arranged in eight piles (the isles).
Each turn the players will select a role (wich give them different powers for the turn), get information about treasures in the map and get a loot from the island they are in.

Tiles can have positive or negative values, and a bluff, strategy and some deduction skills can make the difference between a rich pirate and a poor and doomed one.

A new resource mechanics and event has been implemented to get an even more estrategic game.

The website is in spanish, but the game isn't language dependant and english rules are available to download.
April 2015 actualization: The final rules are finally translated and reference cards are in english too)

item.description:
A curse is cast on you, which transports you to the magical land of Norkobia. You wish to return to your earthly existence, but Lord Maldorf, ruler of Norkobia, will not let you go unless you meet his demands and build him an enormous empire.

In Warlock, you must use the skills and powers of mythical creatures such as giants, wizards and gnomes to build your empire and thwart your opponents. Each card offers four possibilities, and by using your cards strategically, you can build the biggest empire, be released to return home, and win the game.

The aim of the game is to build an empire next to your castle, with cards that are laid out in a 4x4 grid. Every turn, players will receive 5 cards. One will be placed in their dungeon (where a card will receive a special ability), another one in Hubba's bar, where all the local creatures gather to be hired by the players. The other three cards are kept in the players' hands. The round continues with an auction where players can use their cards to purchase others. Once the auction is done, players can use their cards' special abilities to expand their empire and thus score points. Beware however of other players, as they can steal some of your cards, or destroy parts of your empire. The game calls for cunning placement of your cards in your empire and shrewd bidding in the auction phase. The game ands after three full rounds, or after a player manages to build his/her 16th city (card) in his/her empire. Points are awarded based on the value of your cities, majority bonuses and the variation of the cities built in your empire.

item.description:
Powerhouses of Wresting! is a two-player dice game. Players take turns rolling five dice to get matching numbers (with 1s and 2s matching each other and 6s being wild). After each roll a player can decide to stop or re-roll unmatched dice, with a failure on the new roll costing a matching die.

There are a few additional rules, e.g. getting all the dice to match allows a player to go "over the top" and start over with more dice.

The rules were originally printed and distributed as "shareware." They are currently available online.

Clashing Blades! is a two-player card game representing a fencing match, played with a standard 52-card deck. The heart cards are used to represent damage and the ace-10 of the other suits are used to play. In each round, players start by simultaneously choosing cards, with play passing to the player threatened with damage after that. Spades are used for attack, diamonds for defense, and clubs for parries and ripostes.

Advanced rules add uses for the extra heart cards (extra-powerful attacks) and face and joker cards (events).

The game was originally released as a printed set of rules in a "shareware" version. A second edition with custom cards is forthcoming from Popcorn Press.

uKloo is an educational "Early Reader Treasure Hunt" game to help teach young children reading basics. It is designed to help reluctant readers and is designed for younger ages (4+).

The goal of the game is to successfully navigate through a series of hidden clue cards to win a surprise.

In uKloo, an adult puts the 'picture helper' poster on the fridge, a door, or a wall and hides a selection of clue cards around the house based on reading level and game length in such a way that the clue cards will form a chain. The last clue is given to the players to begin the game.

For competitive mode, two or more chains of clues need to be created to see which child will finish first.

uKloo has been awarded Creative Child Magazine 2011 Game of the Year and is a Dr. Toy 10 Best Active Products and 100 Best Children's Products winner.

The game box includes 42 clue cards with 3 colour-coded levels of achievement, a "Picture Helper" reference poster, 12 blank "Surprise" cards, and information about the creation of the game and future releases.

Swim, spawn, and eat shrimp while avoiding sharks! In Let Them Eat Shrimp!, players place fish tiles (in various geometric shapes) in an effort to spawn (by covering fish eggs on the board) and receive more fish tiles. The fish can also eat shrimp (to gain victory points) and must avoid sharks (which will eat your fish, fish eggs, and shrimp).

Let Them Eat Shrimp! has two ways to play. The beginner's game is suitable for younger players, while the advanced version adds more strategy and depth, as well as more danger; in this version of the game, players might be knocked out early if they can't spawn quickly enough or if their eggs are devoured by the roaming sharks. The game also includes multiple game board components, which can be mixed and match for variety and various skill levels.

BATTLETECH: DOMINATION is a deck-building card game for 2 players set in the BattleTech/MechWarrior universe. Both players start with a small deck of weak cards and strive to build a deck that dominates their opponent with an army of powerful BattleMechs, combat vehicles, infantry, and advanced technology. Support, Resource, and Attack cards also generate powerful effects to help you achieve dominance on the battlefield. At the end of the game, the players score points for each LosTech card in their deck while subtracting points for any Overrun cards in their deck.

BTD v4.1 is the the current version of the game as of 12/10/2016 and contains a total of 205 cards.

item.description:
It is the year 562, the Age of the Diaspora. Humanity, established in hundreds of worlds throughout the known universe, is fighting for survival against cruel alien races, and even against each other as confronted by disputes that appear increasingly absurd.

One world after another is engulfed by the fury of the war while the contenders are fighting ruthlessly to prevent Total Extinction.

Total Extinction is a futuristic wargame with miniatures of 28mm for 2 or more players.

Players take command of a battalion of troops from one of the Star Nations (Glorlon, Union of Colonies, Regulatory Corporation, Elohim, Skraldar or Theocracy) facing a relentless war for survival. Each battalion is divided into units consisting of between 1 and 9 miniatures and led by a commander.

The game is divided into a series of turns (typically up to 6) which can be solved in about 2 hours. On each turn, alternately, players are activating their units that can move, shoot and even assault enemy units to take control of key areas of the battlefield (Objectives) and win the game. To achieve the victory, the armies also have the help of their commanders, who, by skillful tactics (represented by cards), can provide better techniques to attain their goals.

item.description:
The HeroClix Man of Steel Mini-Game is thematically based on the Movie, Man of Steel. The game is at its core a face off between Superman and General Zod. These characters each lead their own faction of fighters into battle in a struggle over the fate of Earth. Each of the two characters and factions are unique and present a different tactical approach to the game.

The game-play operates under normal HeroClix rules which must be accessed at HeroClix.com. In its barest form the game operates through a set of abilities possessed by each character such as movement, attack, defense, etc. A certain number of actions can be assigned per turn to use these abilities. There are several strategies in this game but only one way to win: eliminate all of the opponents characters from the board. The path to this ultimate goal rests on a player's ability to successfully maneuver around the playing field and utilize the special super powers of General Zod and Superman.

Includes:
1 Superman #101 miniature
1 General Zod #106 miniature
2 Character cards
1 Full Color Game Board
2 Dice (Six Sided)
32 Tokens(Two factions)

Each player has 3 pawns of the same color. The first player to group together all 3 of his/her pawns is the winner.

Players first play turns in which they place their pawns on the board; each pawn of a single player has to be on a differently colored board space. Players then in turn move one of their 3 pawns.

There's also single a 'neutral piece' that all players get to move once during their turn.

Knight Line is a minimalist connection game for two players.

Each player has 20 square tiles in their colour; at the start of the game, these tiles are placed in two adjacent stacks, one of each colour.
 
A move consists of moving part of a stack (at least one tile must be left behind) to an empty space by making a knight's move. All pieces must be connected at least diagonally throughout the game.

The first player to make a line of 4, orthogonally or diagonally, wins.

To offset the first player advantage, they must move only a single piece on their first move.

item.description:
Golden Pyramids is a boardgame in which players go exploring an ancient pyramid in search of treasure.

The inside of the pyramid is explored as the players go adventuring from room to room. Players will have to find their way around by placing ladders, moving mummies around, collecting keys and opening doors.

At times, all players will need to cooperate in order to get deeper into the pyramid. But when there's treasure in sight, it's every adventurer for him or herself!

Each player has two explorers with which to search through the pyramid. The main goal is of course the Kings Chamber and the treasure within it. Be warned though: the moment the Kings Chamber is discovered, the spirit of the Pharaoh will descend from the heavens in order to keep the explorers from escaping with his riches. Now the race for the exit is on as all that are still inside the pyramid will be trapped forever once the Pharaoh's spirit seals the pyramid shut!

Quiddler Junior is a card game in which players try to score the most points possible by creating words from the letters in their hand.

The game lasts six rounds, with players receiving 2-7 letter cards each round: two the first round, three the second, etc. Players play simultaneously, drawing and discarding one card at a time until a player can use all of his letters to create a word and go out. Each other player draws and discards one final time, then creates the most valuable word possible. Players score points for the value of their word, and the player with the longest word each round scores 5 bonus points. (Some cards have more than one letter on them, allowing for words that have more letters than the number of cards.)

Whoever has the most points after six rounds wins!

Trivia game in which the players have to answer questions about occidental culture: History, Literature, Art, Music, Philosophy and Science.

El Juego de la Cultura (The Game of Culture) contains a board, six pawns, a die and 600 cards with questions, answers and explanations. The boardgame is sold together with the book "La cultura: todo lo que hay que saber" (The Culture: Everything you need to know or Bildung: Alles was man wissen muß in the original Edition in German) by Dietrich Schwanitz. The original edition of both the game and the book is German.

This is a very simple and old-fashioned "Roll&Move" trivia game.

The players roll the die, move the pawn and answer questions about occidental culture. The topic (History, Literature, Art, Music, Philosophy and Science) is determined by the color of the space that the pawn has moved on. The player has to choose between three possible answers. For example:
- Who is the author of "The portrait of Dorian Gray": (A) William Faulkner, (B) Charles Dickens or (C) Oscar Wilde.

The answer to the question can be found in the back of the card. There are a few spaces in the track with special rules, such as the player loses a turn (jail) or go back to Start (sarcophagus).

The first player that reaches the end of the track and responds correctly a question on a topic chosen by the other players wins.

The answer to all the questions can be also found in the accompanying book "La cultura: todo lo que hay que saber" (The Culture: Everything you need to know or Bildung: Alles was man wissen muß in the original Edition in German) by Dietrich Schwanitz.

In Five Crowns Junior, players try to match all five cards in their hand by color or suit. The first player to do so gains a treasure chest, and the player with the most chests wins.

The game lasts five rounds, and one of the suits is wild each round. Each player starts with a hand of five cards, and players play simultaneously, drawing and discarding one card until someone is able to go out. Once a player does so, each other player has one final turn; for each card that a player can't match, she receives a packrat chip. If players tie for treasure chests after five rounds, the player with the fewest packrat chips wins.

Katapult is a game of skill and strategy where players have to bounce their balls accurately in the rooms of the castle to control the largest possible number and respond to attacks of their opponents.

Integrate kings your game to increase the difficulty of the game.

On each of your turn, you bounce a ball on your "trampoline" to send it in one of the 16 "rooms" in the castle. You win points by controlling (majority of balls) those rooms in certain combination (3 or 4 in a row, or the 4 center rooms) at the end of the round (when everyone has no more balls to throw). The game ends after a couple of rounds totalling the points from each round and highest score wins.

name.value: Colossal Cave Adventure: The Card Game

item.description:
Colossal Cave Adventure: The Card Game is based on the 350-point ADVENT computer game created by Will Crowther and expanded by Don Woods. As that game is in the public domain, this adaption is placed in the public domain as well.

The game captures the spirit of the first text adventure: the feel of exploring, mapping, and navigating a new world, while trying to find the items that will solve the puzzles.

To setup, you deal location cards face down to form 3 levels of the cave: each level is a 5 by 5 grid. The entrance chamber is placed in the center of the first level and players' pawns start there.

From a location card, players can only travel in directions indicated by the location, moving to one permitted adjacent card and exploring that location. Sometimes they encounter obstacles ("A fierce green snake bars the way!") and have to turn back unless they have the current item; typically they encounter new regions of the cave ("You are in a maze of twisty little passages, all alike. [Lose a turn!]"), some of which allow them to choose from an item deck ("There is a shiny brass lamp nearby"). The cave is confusing and complex - often you can't simply return to a location you recently left, but must plot a course through other regions or levels to get there. Magic words will take you up and down levels of the cave.

To win, players race to be the first to score 100 points in items collected and puzzles solved or solve the end game puzzle before anyone else.

Hop is an abstract strategy game with simple rules and generic material. An 8x8 board, 16 black and 16 white stones is all you need.

Starting with your stones on the first 2 lines of your side of the board your goal is to move one of your stones to the opponent's end. To get there stones can only move by jumping vertically or horizontally over at least one adjacent stone (or a row of stones) of any color composition onto the next free field. But be careful! Finding the right balance between offense and defense is key. Because whenever you don't jump forward on your turn, your opponent may say "Hop", forcing you to a second move that MUST be forward. But using the "Hop" rule in the right moment yourself can free the way to victory!

Find the complete rules in the Files section.

item.description:
This is a miniature, portable edition of Monopoly. The board is roughly 3/4 the size of a normal monopoly board and is stored in a miniature case. There are several clips so that the game state can be saved and preserved without the pieces scattering. The game design is really geared towards portability and the ability to play the game in several segments of time.

Components

Compact Gameboard 
6 movers 
6 location clips 
6 money clips 
28 Title Deed cards 
16 Chance cards 
16 Community Chest cards 
1 pack of MONOPOLY money 
32 house clips 
12 hotel clips 
2 dice 
Instructions

The goal of Moocho Sudooko is to be the player with the most tiles on the board and the least amount left in your pile.

Players place tiles by rolling two D6 and the adding, subtracting, multiplying or dividing the two results to get a number between 1 and 9. The player then places the tile on the board, a 9 by 9 grid representing a sudoku board. Tiles must be placed such that they don't break the rules of sudoku. The game ends when no possible legal move can be made (whether or not the puzzle is completed).

Star Realms is a spaceship combat deck-building game by Magic Hall of Famers Darwin Kastle (The Battle for Hill 218) and Rob Dougherty (Ascension Co-designer).

Star Realms is a fast paced deck-building card game of outer space combat. It combines the fun of a deck-building game with the interactivity of Trading Card Game style combat. As you play, you make use of Trade to acquire new Ships and Bases from the cards being turned face up in the Trade Row from the Trade Deck. You use the Ships and Bases you acquire to either generate more Trade or to generate Combat to attack your opponent and their bases. When you reduce your opponent’s score (called Authority) to zero, you win!

Multiple decks of Star Realms and/or Star Realms: Colony Wars, one for every two people, allows up to six players to play a variety of scenarios. Also, in the newest version, there are new ways to play that allow up to 6 players with modes like Boss, Hunter, and Free for All. You can also add Star Realms Colony Wars to the deck to make it 4 players.

				
					Factions

Each of the cards in the 80 card Trade Deck is a Ship or a Base belonging to one of four factions: The Trade Federation, The Blobs, The Star Empire or The Machine Cult.

				
					Trade Federation

In the far future, the more traditional governing bodies of the human race have been replaced with corporate leadership. The earth and its surrounding colonies are ruled by a group of corporations called the Trade Federation. The Federation’s policies are focused around trade and growth, but especially in profit and prosperity for those at the top of the corporate ladder. While they prefer to deal with other star realms using trade and diplomacy, they have a large defense branch dedicated to protecting the Federation’s trade and other interests.

				
					The Blobs

These mysterious creatures are the first alien life forms encountered by the human race. Most of the initial encounters consisted of human colonies being completely obliterated. On the few occasions that a Blob ship has been recovered somewhat intact, the only biological remains found inside have consisted of a gelatinous mass, thus leading to the moniker, “The Blobs”. While for several years all encounters between humanity and the Blobs have been extremely violent, there is currently some limited trade between various Blob factions and some of the more daring human traders.The Blobs are best at generating massive amounts of Combat and at removing undesirable cards from the Trade Row.

				
					Star Empire

The Star Empire consists primarily of former colonies of the Trade Federation. These colonies were on the outer edges of the Federation. Not only did they feel used by the corporations, but they felt the Federation failed to give them adequate protection from the Blobs. As a result, one ambitious colonial governor was able to unite several colonies into an independent empire under his control, one with a strong military, both for warding off the Blobs and for discouraging the Federation from trying to reclaim their lost colonies. The Star Empire is a combat oriented faction that draws lots of cards and makes the opponent discard cards.

				
					Machine Cult

A cluster of industrial mining worlds were completely cut off from the Trade Federation by the Blobs. With the threat of annihilation by the Blobs always looming and no contact with the rest of human space, these worlds were forced to take drastic measures. Soon a cult of technology arose, focused on using advanced technology, robotics and computerization to create strong defenses and a powerful military that belied their relatively small population. Since their leaders believed their salvation lay in technology, technology soon became their god and their religion. The Machine Cult gains most of its power from being able to remove undesirable cards from your deck and from having a large number of Bases designed to defend your Authority from attack.

				
					Playing Star Realms

â€‹When you play Star Realms, you will be able to acquire and use Ships and Bases of any and all of the four factions. Many cards have powerful Ally abilities that reward you for using Ships and Bases of the same faction together, however.

As you acquire cards using Trade, you put them into your discard pile, to be later shuffled into your personal deck. When you draw Ships, you do what they say and they get placed into your discard pile at the end of your turn. When you draw a Base, you play it face up in front of you and may use its abilities once every turn. In addition to Combat being the way you reduce your opponent’s Authority to zero and win the game, it’s also useful for destroying your opponent’s Bases. Some Bases are designated as Outposts. Your opponent’s Outposts must be destroyed before you can use Combat to attack your opponent’s Authority directly.

Star Realms is easy to learn, especially if you’re familiar with deck-building games, but it’s a game that takes time to master. Each time you play, the game is filled with various strategic decision points. Should I take the best card for me or the best card for my opponent? Should I focus on taking cards of a particular faction or on taking the best card available? Should I be focusing on acquiring more Trade or more Combat? Should I attack my opponent’s Base or their Authority? These are just some of the many choices you’ll be faced with. New players needn’t agonize over these choices just to play, but as they become more advanced players, they will find this depth of strategy leads to great replayability.

item.description:
In the movie-making game Hollywood, each player is a studio boss who tries to produce the most successful blockbuster. Players construct movies from game cards that they draft or purchase. Players compete to get the most popular stars to perform in their movies because this brings them more money and more Hollywood Awards (which are pictured on some cards).

First, players take turns choosing cards with the aid of drafting. Second, players purchase additional star cards (the strongest cards in the game) at the auction. Third, each player uses his nine cards in hand to make one or several movies. A movie must have a minimum of three cards: a Script, a Director and an Actor (or Actress). Additional cast members are optional, but they add to a movie's total box office. Quality films bring a large amount of profit to the player.

Players go through three production years, then after the third year Hollywood Awards bring extra money to the players, and the richest player wins.

item.description:
Ahoi Saale abwärts! is a roll-and-move game, where players attempt collect the most points before reaching the Elbe river. Each turn, a player rolls the die and moves that many spaces forward. If he ends on a special space, some event occurs. If he ends on a (red) victory point space, he collects one victory point.

Produced by Ravensburger; published during 1950's.

Life’s a Beach is a tactical game in which you try to corner the market for deckchairs on your local beach. Families of varying size and requirements will visit the beach and you will have to compete for their custom. Where is the best place to pitch your umbrella? Should you move your boat further along the coast? Do you want to erect your windbreak now or later? Or will you resort to other tactics, such as collapsing and removing your rival's beach furniture? And don’t forget to use that space you reserved early with your towel...

Game play is simple. On your turn you either player 2 cards or draw 2 cards. If you play two identical cards, you can take their common action three times. If you play two different cards, you can take their respectives actions once each. Or you can discard any two cards to take any one action of your choice.

Actions include: pitching, moving, or erecting a deckchair, umbrella, windbreak, or boat; collapsing or removing a rival's deckchair, umbrella, windbreak, or boat; walking a family across the beach; or placing your towel down to reserve that space for later use. The play who manages these actions best wilns the game.

Galaxy is an 'Invent your own game' game by Fred Horn. It's a 100-card deck of custom playing cards with which you can design your own game.

The deck consists of the following:

- 2 'saturn cards'
- 2 'comet cards' 
- 6 sets of 16 cards (96 total). Each of these cards show a combinations of 2 numbers in 2 different colors.

The colors used are red, white, yellow and blue and each has a different celestial body associated with it. Red is Mars, white is the moon, yellow is the sun and blue is the earth.

The combinations used are the following:
white and yellow
white and blue
white and red
blue and red
red and yellow
yellow and blue

Each set of 16 cards is made up of the following (matrix):
- 4 cards showing the sequence: 1/1 - 1/2 - 1/3 - 1/4
- 4 cards showing the sequence: 2/1 - 2/2 - 2/3 - 2/4
- 4 cards showing the sequence: 3/1 - 3/2 - 3/3 - 3/4
- 4 cards showing the sequence: 4/1 - 4/2 - 4/3 - 4/4
with the digits to the left of the slash always being the same color. The digits to the right of the slash as also all in the same color, but always a different color than the digit on the left (see the color combinstion mentioned earlier).

Besides these 100 cards there are also 9 white/blank cards as well as a card showing some details about the game and its designer.

In the card and dice game Double Up, you set the challenge. Do you play it safe and choose a challenge that’s easy for both you and your opponents? Or do you raise the bar and pick a tough one, betting your friends will fail where you’ll succeed?

The starting player attempts to match a pattern on a card using a specified number of dice and a hand of roll modifying cards. The player has a fixed number of attempts and dice, as indicated on the card, to successfully complete the challenge. If successful, the rest of the players must attempt the same challenge card and beat it in as many or fewer attempts than the original player. If the player fails to beat the challenge, whoever set the challenge gains a point; if the challenge is a Double Up card, however, they gain two points. The challenge is over once each player has made an attempt. The next player starts a new challenge and the game continues until one person reaches an agreed upon number of points. Double Up your opponents often to win!

Larceny is a heist-themed party game for 3+ players. Gather your crew, pick the Score and plan your heist!

Each round one player is the Chief, everyone else is the Crew. The Chief draws a Score from the deck. This card is what the Crew is stealing during the heist. The Chief then draws two Catches, which are problems that crop up during the heist.

The Crew now has to play Fix cards from their hand to try to over come the Catches. Once everyone has played a Fix on each Catch, the Chief decides which Fix is the best, and points are awarded. Next round someone else is the Chief, and play continues.

Larceny has numerous variant gameplay modes. Most notable are the versus Troubleshooters mode, the cooperative Heist mode, the strategic planning Black Bag mode, and the narrative Best Laid Plan mode.

From rules (translated):

In Harkinta-peli (Consideration) you play with differences: shapes, colors, sizes and thicknesses. Each play tile has their own special properties and each property gives one point. No tile is exactly the same as another. In this game a child can learn with an adult to see the differences in the tiles and in which way a tile differs from one or more other tiles.

Observation capabilities develop and after a few rehearse tries the player is able to pick out the best place for a tile on the board so that it differs as much as possible from the previous tiles, at the same time making it harder for the other players to find good placements, thus keeping them from gaining points.

In this game you have to think forward, plan your next move and rethink your moves when your opponents do not play a tile that would've given the most points.

(Year published is a guess based on picture)

name.value: Marvel Avengers: Captain America vs. Loki

item.description:
Use up all your cards to win in an epic battle between Captain America and Loki.

There are 4 types of cards: Captain America cards and Loki cards are numbered 1-5, there are also switch cards and wild cards.

Players are dealt 5 cards and the first player selects a card to play, then players take turns playing 1 card. If a Captain America card was played previously, the next card played must be a Captain America card with a higher number. If a Loki card was played previously a Loki card with a lower number must be played. You can play a Loki card on a Captain America or vice versa if the numbers on both are the same.

A wild card can be played at any time. When a wild card is played that player plays a second card of their choice. The switch card can also be played at any time. This card changes play from Loki or Captain America to the opposite character. The next player may then play any value of the new character card.

If a player cannot play a card they draw a card. If the drawn card is playable it can be played otherwise it goes in the player's hand. The first player to play all their cards wins.

Put your keen eyes and reflexes to the test. Smash your way to victory! Collect the most "Target" cards by smashing (slapping) the right cards to win.

Game contains 10 Target cards and 38 Smash cards. The Target cards tell you what to smash.

On your turn flip over a card from the Target deck for all to see. Then take the Smash deck into your hand and flip over Smash cards one at a time, forming a discard pile in the middle.

All the other players look for the right card to "smash" (slap). The first player to smash the right card wins the Target card and the turn passes to the next player. Continue until all the Target cards have been claimed. The player with the most Target cards plus Hulk Fists wins.

(2-player variant included)

name.value: Marvel Avengers: Iron Man Armor Up

item.description:
Harness the power of Iron Man's Repulsor technology and battle against Loki the trickster! Be the first player to use all your cards to win.

There are 7 types of cards—Iron Man's Energy Shield, Repulsor Blast, or Flight cards, the Avengers cards, the Tesseract and Counter Attack cards, and the Loki cards.

On your turn play one card from your hand following the rules for that card. If you are unable to play any card, you must draw a card and end your turn. Continue playing until one player has used all their cards.

name.value: Pearl Harbor Attack Thunderfish Torpedo Strike
Tunderfish at Pearl Habor: Re-enactment Game Guide

item.description:
Tired of small gaming counters, sluggish play processes, or the mindless arcade play of many computer war games? Want more realism, direct action play, and observable battle results without losing the lively historic qualities. Historians and gamers will find the game pace, play method, and varied outcomes to be fascinating. Parents, teachers, and students will recognize the great advantage of learning while playing.

This game is part of a larger "Re-enactment Guide" for the attack on Pearl Harbor.

In this game, you make duplicate copies of the battleship target illustrations and the numberd "Special Factors" cards. Then follow the simple attack procedures against each battleship. Damage scores will vary depending where the torpedo hit occurs plus a random number variation. Hence, player can expect a different outcome each time they play the game. The game can be plyed solo to in small groups.

Play as the IJN torpedo bomber force armed with the secret shallow water Type 91 Mod. 2 "Thunderfish" torpedo as they attack American battleships in Pearl Harbor. The attack that ended the battleship era. Game variables include, increasing anti-aircraft resistance, aborted & recycled attack attempts, torpedo stuck in mud, and a variable math expression to calculate damage/flooding calculations. Final game score can be matched against the historical recorded or tallied in other ways (percent damage and/or number of hits).

Games will be mailed in a large envelope.
 Printed Game Parts Include:
•Rules of Play

•Illustrated "Graphic" Activity Diagram

•Pearl Harbor Map (letter size paper)

•Battleship Torpedo Target Illustrations (Gray scale prints on legal size 20# paper format) USS Nevada, USS Arizona, USS West Virginia, USS Oklahoma, and USS California

•Special Impact Overlay Transparency

•Score Sheets

•Special Affects/Randomizing Number (print & cut) Game Cards

[Game Parts, Target Illustrations, and Score Sheets are Copyrighted but can be reproduced for non-commercial use by the individual purchaser for years of play in your home or in your school classroom]
Kidz Cardz treatment of Go Fish, Old Maid, War, and Crazy Eights. The 4 decks come individually boxed in cardboard and in a big tin.

On turn, each player rolls the die and answers the question according to the category shown on the die. Score pad is used to keep track of the score. Game ends after a set time limit or after all cards have been used once. The person with most points is the official whisky champion. Most of the questions are multiple choise.

Re-roll
Each player has 2 re-rolls during the game.

Ask a friend
Helping player gets 2 points and the player gets 1 on a correct answer

Question categories:
Production
Geography
Brands
Occasion & Taste
Trivia
Other

Game includes
71 Quiz cards
Rules
Custom dice
Score pad
Pencil

item.description: Tennis Cards emulates a game of tennis, with players taking it in turns to select shots from their hand in an attempt to win the point. Each player has only a limited number of cards per game and so must be careful to balance staying in a rally with card conservation.

Contents:
One Board
1 rules sheet
4 letter racks
100 wooden tiles

Word game. Separate the vowels from the consonants. Up to four players draw 3 Vowels and 7 consonants. After everyone has their starting 10 tiles, the remaining tiles are mixed together and left face-down as a draw pile. Words are formed vertically or horizontally but two words going in the same direction cannot be formed if it does not leave a space between the letters of both words. The box illustrates this rather well. If you cannot make a legal play, you draw one tile. If you can now play a word, you do so. If not, draw another tile, and so on. If you cannot make a play after drawing three tiles, your turn ends. The winner is the first player to get rid of all his tiles.

In addition, on the board there are some coloured squares. Should your word cross such a square, you must do the following:

Yellow field: Randomly pick a tile from the right neighbour.
Red box: Give the left neighbour a random tile.
Blue field: Take three tiles from the existing stock.
Green field: You must swap one of your tiles with another player. Both players choose a tile for the swap and the tiles are swapped face-down.

'Thick as Thieves' is a cooperative board game based on the idea that all players are working together to steal an item from a well guarded museum. You’ll have to work together to infiltrate the system, sneak past guards, and get past the alarms and locked doors. Be careful though, there isn't always honor amongst thieves. At any time, if the opportunity presents itself, a player may choose to betray everyone and steal a secondary item they've been eye-balling since before the heist even started!

Each player is a thief with different abilities moving silently (hopefully) around the museum at night dodging roaming guards and security cameras. When they reach a designated location, they attempt a challenge based on an attribute that each character has a varying amount of (Brawn, Brains, Sneak, Charm).

Once they succeed in their challenge, players get to choose a card that allows them to trigger a change in the board's circumstances. They can turn off security cameras, move guards, turn off the lights, unlock doors or turn off alarms. If everything goes smoothly, your team will work like clockwork to steal the one item you're all here for. If all goes smoothly.

Not only do the players have to work precisely, but they have to work quickly before the next guard shift comes in. As the game progresses, a deck of cards is pulled changing the position of the guards and moving the clock ever so dangerously close to the end of the game. Get your item out of the museum before the deck runs out!

UNAUTHORIZED PRODUCTION

 
 
 The information that BGG has on this item indicates that Journey to Zion is a non-authorized version of Ticket to Ride, thus it is set apart from the official entry.

 


From the publisher:

Recreate the trips the saints took, and score points by making the longest journeys. Perfect for the whole family.

Object: Make your way by train, ship, steamboat, handcart, or covered wagon to Zion. Be the first one to score 100 points. Points can be scored by completing a trail between two points, completing a journey card.

UNRELEASED GAME

 
 
 Note that all details for this game are preliminary. If you have information about this game, you are invited to edit this section or submit corrections.

 


For now only the Moobie title and other basic information is available.

Oh no! The sneaky wolf has entered the farmhouse! He might already have disguised himself as a sheep, a hunter or a hunting dog. In order to confuse the wolf, the hunter and animals in the farmhouse also start to disguise themselves. As a result, nobody can tell each other apart anymore. Meanwhile, the shepherd boy has repeatedly fooled others by crying out "Wooolf! Wooolf!!". So the hunter and the hunting dog have to be careful with the shepherd boy. Everyone has to find out the real identity of others. Will the wolf finally catch the real sheep, or can the sheep find the hunter and the hunting dog who can protect them?

Wooolf!! Is a fast playing deduction game suitable for four to eight players. Each player has two character cards, one of which represents his true identity and the other is only there to cause confusion. Character cards include wolf, sheep, shepherd boy, hunter, and hunting dog. By asking clever questions and drawing the right conclusions, each player tries to make correct suspicions before the other players do. In order to catch the wolf, the shepherd boy will sometimes dress up as hunter, the hunter will disguise as a sheep, the sheep will act like hunting dogs and the hunting dog will put on wolf skin. Use your wits to tell truth from lies in order to be the first to catch the wolf.

item.description:
"Fleas from around the world have come to compete in a race of grueling speed and agility known as the Grand Flix. Only one champion will emerge from the ranks to become the most legendary flea of all time!"

The Grand Flix is a dexterity racing game in which two to four players take turns launching, flicking, and spinning discs over the playing surface. Each player controls a single flea disc and must navigate obstacles and complete checkpoints in numeric order before landing on the finish line. Checkpoints and obstacles are double sided and are flipped during game play to create an ever-changing race course. The goal for each player is to be the first to land their flea on the finish line.

The Grand Flix does not utilize a playing board and is only limited by the flat surface it is played on. 
 Designed to fit into a 100ml tin, the Grand Flix is a compact and easily transportable game.

item.description:
Monopoly: My Little Pony features the familiar Monopoly gameplay, with players rolling dice and moving their tokens around the game board while trying to buy or trade for sets of property in order to bankrupt everyone else and win the game.

The figure tokens in Monopoly: My Little Pony are miniatures of the ponies in the television show – Rarity, Fluttershy, Rainbow Dash, Twilight Sparkle, Pinkie Pie and Applejack – while the property locations include Cutie Mark Clubhouse, Everfree Forest, Sweet Apple Acres, Manehattan, and the Crystal Empire.

Roll the white die and your colored die. Do they match? Yes? All right, max points! No? Ok, let's use the cards!

When the color dice numbers don't match the white, use numbered cards to increase or decrease the color dice number. Or use your special card to reroll the color dice, change the white dice number or to change the opponents game.

After 5 rounds, the one with most points win the game, but don't forget to count the number of cards that you played during the game!

name.value: The Witcher: El juego de aventuras

item.description:
The Witcher Adventure Game takes players on a journey across the world of The Witcher, a detailed world, rich in lore and characters, fleshed out by Andrzej Sapkowski's famous series of novels, and honed by The Witcher video game trilogy.

Players assume the roles of four distinct characters from this series: Geralt of Rivia, monster slayerÍ¾ Triss Merigold, cunning sorceressÍ¾ Yarpen Zigrin, dwarven warriorÍ¾ and Dandelion, roguish bard. Each character has unique skills and multiple ways of overcoming obstacles, but you decide what to do during the game: Do you fight your way to victory, call on your charm, or try your hand at diplomacy? You can bring enemies around to your point of view with a sword as Geralt - or bribe them with gold and threaten to call on powerful friends as Dandelion. If a situation calls for strength in numbers, Yarpen has his own fellowship of dwarves to command, and Triss can rely on her expert skill with magic to save the day.

Each character has its own deck of Development Cards, so each time you play you can discover something new by trying out varied characters and experimenting with different builds. For example, when playing as Geralt of Rivia, the main hero of the Witcher franchise, you can develop your character either by specializing in brewing and utilizing combat Elixirs, or else by growing your ability to cast powerful Witcher Signs.

A variety of quests invite players to hunt monsters, earn gold and interact with the characters they meet in a web of alliances and treachery. Decide whether you’ll help the other players or look after your own interests first, and keep an eye on the progress of your friends while you carefully work your way towards victory.

item.description:
2 to 4 Players relive the golden age of American arcades by starting their own. Each round vintage arcade equipment cards like pinball machines, foosball, ping pong, pool tables and video game machines are auctioned off. Players must manage which machines make them money and how much space the equipment takes up in their rented back rooms. "High score" cards are earned each round by players who best use the space available to them or earn the most tokens.

Each round players must: adjust which equipment cards they will use and what goes into storage... Repair equipment that is out of order,.. And choose whether to advertise. Tokens are earned each pay day by the roll of dice. Some equipment will earn more tokens and some offer a greater probability of earning. Players also decide each round to purchase newly available equipment, or steal opponents equipment that they have in storage. The game ends when a player collects 11 or more high score cards.
